pullRequest.body:
This PR adds some basics about monoidal opposite categories and their relation to the original category, as well as the Yang-Baxter equation for braided monoidal categories. It should be easy to define an action of the braid group on an object of a braided monoidal category from this.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7935261045/job/21668000876)

~~> ```suggestion~~
~~@[simps!] def MonoidalOpposite.mopMopEquivalence : Cᴹᵒᵖᴹᵒᵖ ≌ C := Equivalence.refl~~
~~```~~
~~ Similarly, you should remove the _ in the definitions below. Otherwise, the PR looks good to me.  ~~

~~Done 🎉~~

I tried to reply from within vscode's github PR extension and the formatting completely broke
In mathlib's coding style, we are supposed to write infix operators like `≫` or `≪≫` at the end of the line rather than at the beginning.
Fixed. It would be nice if the linter could catch this

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion (α_ X Y Z).inv ≫ ((β_ X Y).hom ▷ Z) ≫ (α_ Y X Z).hom ≫ ```

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion (α_ X Y Z).symm ≪≫ whiskerRightIso (β_ X Y) Z ≪≫ α_ Y X Z ≪≫ ```
I am afraid `=` is also an infix operator, so that it should be at the end of the line.
🤦‍♂️. Fixed

I would think that the following statement would be more in the spirit of the current API:
```suggestion
theorem yang_baxter' (X Y Z : C) :
    ((β_ X Y).hom ▷ Z) ⊗≫ (Y ◁ (β_ X Z).hom) ⊗≫ ((β_ Y Z).hom ▷ X) =
      𝟙 _ ⊗≫ ((X ◁ (β_ Y Z).hom) ⊗≫ ((β_ X Z).hom ▷ Y) ⊗≫ (Z ◁ (β_ X Y).hom)) ⊗≫ 𝟙 _ := by
  rw [← cancel_epi (α_ X Y Z).inv, ← cancel_mono (α_ Z Y X).hom]
  convert yang_baxter X Y Z using 1
  all_goals coherence
```

You should add the attribute `@[simp, reassoc]` to the four lemmas `braiding_tensor_left` et al, so that you could simplify this proof:
```suggestion
  rw [← braiding_tensor_right_assoc X Y Z, ← cancel_mono (α_ Z Y X).inv, assoc, assoc,
    assoc, assoc, assoc, assoc, Iso.hom_inv_id, comp_id,
    ← braiding_naturality_right X (β_ Y Z).hom, braiding_tensor_right]
```
(Note that `@[reassoc (attr := simp)]` would be the correct spelling if the LHS of the lemmas was a composition, but when only the RHS is `@[simp, reassoc]` is useful.)
I would rather not touch those at the moment, since this will already need to be fixed up once #6307 is merged

I am only suggesting to take the opportunity to fix 4 missing `reassoc` attributes and cleaning up a proof (which would become a sequence of `rw`, which is the easiest to maintain). I do not see any drawback to this.
Fair enough
In this proof (and also similar proofs below), it would be advisable to use sequences of `rw` (or maybe `erw` if is it necessary), and probably use `_assoc` versions of some lemmas.
Oh I didn't realize erw would work, nice! I haven't really used that tactic before
Do we need a simp in this direction? The opposite seems more likely to me.
The fact that that's inconsistent with the direction of the simp for refl, trans doesn't feel right to me

I found the similar lemma `inv_whiskerLeft` has the opposite direction `inv (X ◁ f) = X ◁ inv f`, which is based on the idea of pushing non-primitive components of monoidal categories inside as much as possible. The identity and the compositions are considered as primitive, but not for `inv`. This has an advantage as we may expect that 

1. `inv f` is further simplified,
2. some lemmas involving the left whiskering can be applied to an expression containing `X ◁ inv f`, but not to `inv (X ◁ f)`.

I think this idea will also work in the case of `Iso`.

Good points. At least like this `whiskerLeftIso_refl` is consistent with `whiskerLeft_id`, `whiskerLeftIso_trans` is consistent with `whiskerLeft_comp`, and `whiskerLeftIso_symm` is consistent with `whiskerLeft_inv`. I've changed it to be as you suggested
I think we need just `simp [← yang_baxter_assoc]` here. We may miss some simp lemmas like `mop (α_ X Y Z).hom = (α_ (mop Z) (mop Y) (mop X)).inv`.
I got (roughly) this to work by adding `@[simps]` to `monoidalCategoryMop`

For `unmopBraidedFunctor` I couldn't get it to happen just with simp, although the proof is much cleaner now. Also it seems that that `@[simps]` attribute breaks the ability of `aesop_cat` to prove `μ_natural_left, μ_natural_right` for `mopBraidedFunctor`. Do you have any suggestions?

Ah, I see why you suggested `mop (α_ X Y Z).hom = (α_ (mop Z) (mop Y) (mop X)).inv` as a simp lemma. That does seem much nicer. I've started adding lemmas like this for mop/op but simp now runs into a stack overflow, so I need to debug first

> Also it seems that that @[simps] attribute breaks the ability of aesop_cat to prove μ_natural_left, μ_natural_right for mopBraidedFunctor.

I think this suggests that adding @[simps] is not a good idea for these instances. In fact, the lemmas provided by simps (which can be seen by putting `set_option trace.simps.verbose true in`)  are different from what we want. I think the following lemmas are helpful, but unfortunately we should add them manually:
```lean
@[simp] theorem mop_associator_hom (X Y Z : C) : (α_ X Y Z).hom.mop = (α_ (mop Z) (mop Y) (mop X)).inv := rfl
@[simp] theorem unmop_associator_hom (X Y Z : Cᴹᵒᵖ) : (α_ X Y Z).hom.unmop = (α_ (unmop Z) (unmop Y) (unmop X)).inv := rfl
```
Yes, I definitely agree putting `@[simps]` where I did is a mistake. I'm in the process of adding lemmas like what you've written and making the existing code use them
The code has been updated with these lemmas
Is there some reasons why you put associators at the both ends in the RHS? I think this is one possible choice, but we also have other choices.
Sorry, I meant LHS, not RHS.

I chose this way of writing it because it becomes an equality of maps `X ⊗ Y ⊗ Z ⟶ Z ⊗ Y ⊗ X`, both the domain and codomain being fully right associated. Also because it's what was easiest for the proof of associativity in `mopBraidedFunctor`. There are other choices we could make but I don't see a reason to prefer another
We don't need parentheses around whiskerings.
I dislike writing a series of infix operators when it's potentially unclear to a human reader what the precedence is, even if it's unambiguous to lean

Much of the mathlib code seems to use as few parentheses as possible (not all, of course). The priority is not obvious from the text, but we can see it by hovering over it in VSCode. I think this is one of the reasons why we don't need parentheses in practice.
Great automation! In addition, `Quiver.Hom.unmop_inj` is redundant and actually no longer needed.

It doesn't work if I remove `Quiver.Hom.unmop_inj` on my machine. Are you possibly using lemmas from `ymizuno-monoidal-whiskering`? We should probably move further discussion to PR reviews in zulip btw

Here we need to use `← yang_baxter_assoc` instead.

> We should probably move further discussion to PR reviews in zulip btw

Sure!
`simp` works
Could you add a simp lemma like `braiding_inv_naturality_right` stating this fact in its own right to `aesop_cat` works. The proof looks fine and I think it is a cleaver use of the API.
`simp` works
We can omit them as `aesop_cat` works.

```suggestion
  @BraidedFunctor.mk C _ _ _ C _ _ (reverseBraiding C) (.id C) fun X Y =>
    (IsIso.eq_inv_comp _).mpr $ (id_comp _).trans $
    (braiding_swap_eq_inv_braiding Y X).trans (comp_id _).symm
```

```suggestion
@[simps!] def MonoidalOpposite.mopMopEquivalence : Cᴹᵒᵖᴹᵒᵖ ≌ C := Equivalence.refl
```
Similarly, you should remove the `_` in the definitions below. Otherwise, the PR looks good to me.
Done 🎉

```suggestion
    tensor Cᴹᵒᵖ ≅ (unmopFunctor C).prod (unmopFunctor C) ⋙
      Prod.swap C C ⋙ tensor C ⋙ mopFunctor C :=
```

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - Feat: Add Yang-Baxter equation and the opposite braided monoidal category
